awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Evidence in Economic Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in economic theory. The team will study the acquisition and use of hard information or evidence which enables interested parties to prove some assertions they wish to make. When can social institutions be designed in such a way as to provide strong enough incentives to interested parties to acquire enough sufficiently credible evidence as to enable efficient outcomes? When efficiency is not possible, what is the nature of the distortions from efficiency generated by the best institutions that are possible? The research team will develop mathematical models for studying these questions, including tools for making the analysis sufficiently tractable to yield clear results. More broadly, the work will facilitate research of applied economic models in this large class of interesting environments. By providing tools for making the analysis more tractable, the research may generate new classes of economic institutions and shed new light on existing ones. The tools will also be useful in studying the structure of organizations, such as firms and governments. 

The project focuses on mechanism design when agents can acquire noisy evidence. The general model has connections to a wide range of economic models of "hard information", such as Bayesian persuasion and models of testing. The team will develop tools for simplifying the mechanism design problem to be able to focus on a more tractable class of mechanisms. In particular, they will develop conditions under which one can identify the evidence the principal will request given any claim by the agent and/or the evidence generation actions the principal will recommend given any type report. Together or separately, this identification will greatly simplify characterization of the optimal mechanism. The investigators will also compare optimal mechanisms to outcomes when the principal cannot commit himself. Finally, they will characterize environments in which efficient outcomes are possible and the nature of distortions when efficiency is not achievable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We are in the process of completing a significant revision of one paper for submission for publication and a second paper that will also be submitted for publication.

In the literature on evidence in economics the standard model has different types of individuals having access to different sets of evidence. We extend this to incorporate two important features. First, individuals choose what evidence to try to obtain. Second, the outcome of that choice may be random.  

We consider two environments. In the first, the individual decides which evidence to present out of whatever is obtained. In the second, simpler environment, the evidence obtained is necessarily observed and the individual has no choice in the matter at that stage. We show how the latter -- which is clearly a special case of the former -- can also encompass the former under certain assumptions about the evidence structure. This connection simplifies the process of finding the optimal mechanism for this environment. Moreover, we find a condition on the evidence structure that further simplifies finding the optimal mechanism by removing the need for the principal to tell the individual what evidence to (try to) obtain.

The literature on evidence also has explored the question of when there is an advantage to the principal to be able to commit to the mechanism. We first obtain a much simpler and more general proof of a result showing no value to commitment by focusing on Nash equilibrium. We then also show how the more general environment we study requires stronger conditions compared to the simpler setting of previous results to obtain the conclusion.

In our second paper we show the relationships between search problems and incentivizing individuals to obtain and provide evidence. The problem we study is one where individuals may, at a cost, obtain evidence that proves their type (e.g., their qualifications for a task they want to be assigned to). A principal decides on a rule for allocating the desired task, in a way that optimally incentivizes the agents to obtain and present the evidence. We use the connection to search models to fully characterize the optimal mechanism and explore its properties.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/23/2023
Modified by: Barton L Lipman
